For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. If you have examples of American Furnace Company (AFCO) brand serial numbers and good photos of the rating plates and systems from any era, please forward them to us for our further research! You can use the form HERE
AFCO brand systems were manufactured between 1900 and 1970. The Singer Furnace Company (subsidiary of Singer Sewing Machine Company) purchased AFCO in 1968 and placed it under the corporation's Climate Control Division. In 1970, Singer renamed AFCO to Singer American Furnace. SnyderGeneral purchased the Singer Climate Control Division in 1982. The Singer American Furnace brand name was dropped by SnyderGeneral Corp. in 1984 after the buyout of 1982.
Only the Comfortmaker name (once a flagship product line of AFCO) currently remains as a distant remnant of this former

guidance_text:
Using the ANSI or CSA standards to determine approximate Date of Manufacture.
Most manufacturers today are required to include the manufacture compliance standard on the data tag. For the U.S. the compliance standard is typically from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number). As these standards are revised or renewed approximately every 4 to 6 years, one can reasonably estimate the year of manufacture within 4-6 years from (af

guidance_text:
Using the ANSI or CSA standards to determine approximate Date of Manufacture.
Most manufacturers today are required to include the manufacture compliance standard on the data tag. For the U.S. the compliance standard is typically from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number). guidance_text:
Using the ANSI or CSA standards to determine approximate Date of Manufacture.
Most manufacturers today are required to include the manufacture compliance standard on the data tag. For the U.S. the compliance standard is typically from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number). As these standards are revised or renewed approximately every 4 to 6 years, one can reasonably estimate the year of manufacture within 4-6 years from (af

guidance_text:
John Wood serial numbers contain a lot of information, including when the heater was manufactured. This can be determined by looking at the first four numbers, ignoring any letter that may start the serial number. Similar to style 2 below with exception that month was used rather than week.
The first two numbers represent the year the water heater was built.
If your heater was built before 2008, the next two numbers represent the month.
If your heater was built after 2008, the next two numbers represent the week.
For Example
Serial number: U0106413635
This heater was manufactured in June 2001
See FAQ guide from John Wood Website

guidance_text:
This is an older John Wood serial number style (prior to 2006 A.O. Smith acquisition of GSW and John Wood brands). The manufacture date can be determined by looking at the last four numbers after the hyphen in the serial number.
The first set of these numbers (after hyphen) represent the year the water heater was built.
The next (last) two numbers (after hyphen) represent the month.
For Example
Serial number: 137945-7503
This heater was manufactured in the 3rd month (March), 1975.
See FAQ guide from John Wood Website

The first two numbers (before hyphen) represent the year the water heater was built.
The next (last) two numbers (before hyphen) represent the month.
For Example
Serial number: 8711-127684
This heater was manufactured in the 11th month (November), 1987.

Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number). As these standards are revised or renewed approximately every 4 to 6 years, one can reasonably estimate the year of manufacture within 4-6 years from (af

Year (fiscal) of manufacture can be determined by using the 1st numerical digit .
The decade must be assumed based on nearest ANSI code date, condition of the unit, and/or refrigerant type used.
The 2nd character represents month of manufacture. (Jan. thru Sept. represented by 1-9;  Oct., Nov., Dec. represented by X, Y, Z respectively)
CAUTION: The second position of this serial number can be a number OR letter.
In this example, the unit was manufactured the 9th month of either 2008 or 2018
ADDITIONAL NOTES:
For this Mitsubishi style, the 2nd character of the serial number represents the month of manufacture. Numbers represent months 1 thru 9 while letters X, Y, Z will represent months 10 thru 12 respectively.

guidance_text:
Slant/Fin utilized sequential serial numbers which varied in format. Unfortunately Slant/Fin closely guarded their numbering system and the manufacturing date could only be determined via contacting their technical assistance directly. Slant/Fin is no longer in business and can no longer be contacted for assistance with the manufacture date of these systems.
If an ANSI or CGA code compliance date is present on the rating plate, it may assist you in narrowing down a year range for the system. Additionally, the date stamp on the gas valve may be of assistance, but may only provide an approximate year the gas valve was replaced.
You may also be able to use our Hints & Tips page for other helpful clues in determining an approximate manufacture year range.
Slant/Fin® History¹

guidance_text:
Using the ANSI or CSA standards to determine approximate Date of Manufacture.
Most manufacturers today are required to include the manufacture compliance standard on the data tag. For the U.S. the compliance standard is typically from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number). As these standards are revised or renewed approximately every 4 to 6 years, one can reasonably estimate the year of manufacture within 4-6 years from (af

guidance_text:
Using the ANSI or CSA standards to determine approximate Date of Manufacture.
Most manufacturers today are required to include the manufacture compliance standard on the data tag. For the U.S. the compliance standard is typically from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). For Canada, a common standard compliance is through the Canada Standards Association Group (CSA). Many times both standards are listed. Regardless, the specific standard will normally be listed on the data tag/plate and followed by the YEAR of the last revision (often the year is placed in parenthesis or follows the hyphen after the specific standard number).
